ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: General concepts in theater, german theater history, and use of the german language.
You get to read a lot of historically important German plays and overall get to familiarize yourself well with German literary history.
A better and more well rounded knowledge of the German theater canon. Better literary analysis skills as well.

Through this course, I received a broad and engaging overview of the history of German theater. (Though nearly two-thirds of our work focused on the period 1770-1840 (which was super interesting!), we also read works written in the 20th and 21st centuries.) Additionally, I was able to practice and improve my German reading and writing skills.
Understanding of many famous works of theater spanning hundreds of years of German history. Ability to read and analyse theatrical texts

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: discussions in class, very interesting material and supplements.
weakness: grading and the focus are based largely on grammar and spelling, not the content.

Strengths: flexible deadlines, very understanding professor, great people in the class, the different literary epochs are very interesting. Weaknesses: most of the discussions were reading based, and the plays can often be very difficult to understand, so often times no one was able to answer the questions or the answers were overall very dry, which made for not very engaging discussions. Would be better if half the class was a lecture on the readings, and the other half we did discussions instead of only doing discussions for the entire 1 hour 45 min.
I was glad that we could read the entirety of plays because of their length and discuss them pretty deeply

Strengths: AMAZING instructor feedback, interesting course material
Weaknesses: Sometimes class discussions got a bit quiet. Accordingly, I may have enjoyed a bit more lecture time to jumpstart conversations, though I also very much enjoyed many of our discussions anyway!
More varied activity during the class

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure, if you're interested in literary analysis in German and would like to read and discuss a lot of classical works. The readings can get pretty intense though for a foreign language, so unless you're dedicated to spending at least 2 x 8 hours a week on this class, you'll be fine but don't expect to get much out of it/find it engaging.

I would definitely recommend this course to both students looking to both learn more about German theater and students who would like to improve their German writing/reading skills! (I also cannot stress how detailed our feedback was enough.)
Yes if youre interested in learning more about German theater. But there might be other more engaging German courses out there too
